perturbation.original_text: Recipient further acknowledges and agrees that all new discoveries, inventions, improvements, processes, formulae, designs, drawings, training materials, original works of authorship, photos, video tapes, electronic images, documentation, trademarks and copyrights (the "Intellectual Property"), that may be developed, conceived, or made by Recipient, alone or jointly with others during her work for the Company, shall be the exclusive property of the Company and shall be deemed a work for hire. Recipient hereby assigns and agrees to assign all Recipient's rights in any Intellectual Property to the Company.
perturbation.changed_text: Recipient further acknowledges and agrees that all new discoveries, inventions, improvements, processes, formulae, designs, drawings, training materials, original works of authorship, photos, video tapes, electronic images, documentation, trademarks and copyrights (the "Intellectual Property"), that may be developed, conceived, or made by Recipient, alone or jointly with others during her work for the Company, shall be the exclusive property of the Company and shall be deemed a work for hire. Recipient hereby retains rights to all Intellectual Property for personal use and portfolio display but agrees to grant the Company a non-exclusive license for commercial purposes.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces a contradiction regarding Intellectual Property rights. Originally, all rights were assigned to the company. The modified version states the Recipient retains rights for personal use, creating ambiguity as to the extent of the Company's ownership and control over Intellectual Property.

perturbation.original_text: The confidentiality and non-use obligations of Recipient will remain in effect after all work for the Company has been completed.
perturbation.changed_text: The confidentiality and non-use obligations of Recipient will remain in effect for five years after all work for the Company has been completed.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces a time limit on the confidentiality obligations that did not exist before. This conflicts with the earlier statement in the main agreement (section 11.7) that the obligations in Exhibit A 'shall survive the termination or expiration of this endorsement agreement, regardless of cause or circumstances'. The contradiction lies in whether the confidentiality obligations are indefinite or limited to five years, raising potential legal questions regarding the duration of these obligations.

perturbation.original_text: All Information, including any copies thereof, in any media, in the possession or control of Recipient and Information embodied or included in any software or data files loaded or stored on computers in the possession or control of Recipient, its agents or employees, shall be removed and returned to the Company upon demand, but no later than the completion of work for the Company.
perturbation.changed_text: All Information, including any copies thereof, in any media, in the possession or control of Recipient and Information embodied or included in any software or data files loaded or stored on computers in the possession or control of Recipient, its agents or employees, *may* be removed and returned to the Company upon demand, but no later than thirty days after written request by the Company.
perturbation.explanation: This change alters the mandatory 'shall be removed' to the permissive 'may be removed' and introduces a timeframe of thirty days following a written request from the Company. This is contradictory because while the original text requires the recipient to return all information by the completion of work for the company, the modified version introduces a condition where the removal and return of the information depend on the company's demand and a subsequent 30-day period. It becomes unclear whether the recipient is obligated to proactively return all information upon work completion or only when specifically requested by the company, potentially creating ambiguity regarding the timing and necessity of returning company information.
